name: Amaryllis brasiliana
distribution: 20 km w. Victor Hugo, Brazil (Southern America)
remarks: HT collection originally from Brazil, flowered at Burbank, CA (USA)

name: Amaryllis brasiliensis
reference: Escritos Damaso Antonio Larranaga 1: 396. 1922 as Amarillis²Nomen nudum²Pub. Inst. Hist. Geog. Uruguay

name: Amaryllis lavrensis
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Amaryllis restingensis
distribution: Guanabara, Rio de Janeiro (Brazil, Southern America)

name: Eithea lagopaivae
distribution: São Paulo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.3897/phytokeys.85.13369 the species epithet is a tribute to Celso do Lago Paiva, environmental analyst at ICMBio, who has collected the plant for the first time and has dedicated his life to the study and conservation of the flora of Brazil

name: Griffinia alba
distribution: Tapera, wooded habitat, Pernambuco (Brazil, Southern America)

name: Griffinia albolineata
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Griffinia arifolia
distribution: Mun Alcobaça: Sto. Antonio, Bahia (Brazil, Southern America)

name: Griffinia capixabae
distribution: Espírito Santo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.327.2.6 the specific epithet, a word of Tupi origin, an indigenous language, honours the people born in the state of Espírito Santo (capixaba). It means land for agriculture (Nascentes 1966), and also refers to the restricted distribution of the species, endemic to the Serra da Mantiqueira Capixaba in the central region of the state

name: Griffinia colatinensis
distribution: Mun. Colatina, Río Paucas, Espirito Santo (Brazil, Southern America)

name: Griffinia meerowiana
distribution: Espírito Santo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.344.3.3 The specific epithet was chosen in honor of our colleague Alan William Meerow.

name: Griffinia paubrasilica
distribution: Mun. Itamarajú, Faz. Pau Brasil; cultivated by P. Ravenna, Bahia (Brazil, Southern America)

name: Habranthus araguaiensis
distribution: Mun. Alto Araguia, Tocantins (Brazil, Southern America)

name: Habranthus botumirimensis
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Habranthus ruber
distribution: Rio Grande do Sul (Brazil, Southern America)

name: Hippeastrum abatinguara
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.571.2.6 Etymology: the specific epithet refers to an indigenous people, the Abatinguaras, who inhabited the southern region of the state of Minas Gerais and were decimated as a result of the colonization of their territory. It is used here as a noun in apposition.

name: Hippeastrum canastrense
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Hippeastrum carassense
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.1007/s00606-022-01805-3 Etymology: 'The specifc epithet refers to Serra of Caraça, the locality to which the new species is endemic'.

name: Hippeastrum curupira
remarks: doi:10.5091/plecevo.95601 Etymology: the specific epithet honours one of the most traditional and popular mythical characters of Brazilian folklore, the Curupira. It is treated as a noun in apposition.

name: Hippeastrum diniz-cruziae
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Hippeastrum idimae
distribution: Rio de Janeiro (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.307.2.6 the specific epithet was chosen after its discoverer, Idimá Gonçalves da Costa, a self-taught amateur botanist who has been very helpful for many years to scientists investigating the species composition of the areas in the northern part of the State of Rio de Janeiro, an area where most of the original cover was removed, but where many unique species have been discovered by Idimá

name: Hippeastrum laklano
distribution: Santa Catarina (Brazil South, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.5091/plecevo.95601 Etymology: 'The specific epithet is a noun in apposition and refers to the Laklãnõ people, member of the Southern Jê linguistic family, who inhabited vast areas of southern Brazil, including almost the entire northern plateau of Santa Catarina'.

name: Hippeastrum lunaris
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.360.2.1 The specific epithet refers to the Vale da Lua, to where the species is confined. The area is so named because of its rock formations along the banks of the ribeirão São Miguel, considered similar to lunar craters.

name: Hippeastrum mauroi
distribution: Mato Grosso (Brazil West-Central, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.360.2.1 The specific epithet honours Mauro Peixoto.

name: Hippeastrum multiflorum
distribution: Rio Grande do Sul (Brazil South, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.5902/2358198035736 Etymology: name refers to the large number of flowers; possibly this is the species of Hippeastrum with the greatest number of flowers (up to 13).

name: Hippeastrum ramboi
distribution: Rio Grande do Sul (Brazil South, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.5902/2358198029456 the specific epithet honours the Priest Balduíno Rambo (1906-1961)

name: Hippeastrum roseoalbum
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Hippeastrum sanfranciscanum
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Hippeastrum velloziiflorum
distribution: Espírito Santo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America);Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America);
remarks: doi:10.1007/s00606-022-01805-3 Etymology: 'The specific epithet makes reference to the amazing resemblance of the flowers and those of some species of Vellozia Vand. (Velloziaceae)'.

name: Hippeastrum verdianum
distribution: Santa Catarina (Brazil South, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.5902/2358198035738 The specific epithet honours MS. Marcio Verdi, botanist and ecologist who located the species during the forest activities inventory of the state of Santa Catarina.

name: Sprekelia spectabilis
reference: Arq. Bot. Estado Sao Paulo new ser. 1: 23, tab. 18. 1938

name: Tocantinia dutilhiana
remarks: doi:10.5902/2358198022860 Etymology: the specific epithet honors one of the first collectors of the species specimens that were located, a professor and researcher, expert in Amaryllidaceae, Dr. Julie Henriette Antoinette Dutilh, of the Universidade Estadual de Campinas (São Paulo, Brazil), which has actively contributed to the advancement of knowledge of the Brazilian Amaryllidaceae.

name: Tocantinia mira
distribution: Mun. Paraná, Río Lajes, Tocantins (Brazil, Southern America)

name: Tocantinia stigmovittata
reference: Balduinia 53: 8, figs. 2 D–F, 4 A– F, 5. 2016 [10 Jul 2016] [epublished]
remarks: doi:10.5902/2358198022860 Etymology: the specific epithet (Latin stigma=stigma and vittatus= marked or ornamented with ribbons or bows) refers to the morphological uniqueness of the stigma of the species that has stigmatic lobes ornamented with lines (ribbons) pink-vinaceous on its margins.

name: Zephyranthes comunelloi
remarks: doi:10.5902/2358198033221Eponymy: the epithet honours Teylor Rodrigo Comunello, an environmental military policeman from the state of Santa Catarina.

name: Zephyranthes flavissima
distribution: Brazil (Rio Grande do Sul, Sta. Catarina) & Argentina (Entre Rios & Corriente

name: Zephyranthes gratissima
distribution: In apricis nemoribus ad Bairro ad Hípica Clevelandiae, civit., Paraná (Brazil, Southern America)

name: Zephyranthes lactea
reference: Trans. Linn. Soc. London, Bot. ser. 2, 4: 495. 1895

name: Zephyranthes lagesiana
distribution: colle ad Lages; culta in Santiago, Santa Catarina (Brazil, Southern America)

name: Zephyranthes microstigma
distribution: Rio Grande do Sul (Brazil South, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Zephyranthes taubertiana
reference: Notizbl. Königl. Bot. Gart. Berlin 1(3): 81. 1895 [26 Nov 1895] : addit. publ.: Gartenflora 45: 281, t. 1427. 1896

name: Zephyranthes uruguaianica
distribution: Rio Grande do Sul (Brazil South, Brazil, Southern America)
